TissueGrowth.jl

TissueGrowth.jl is a open source project package developed to simulate the evoluition of biological tissue interface during tissue growth. Our model considers mechanical interactions between neighbouring cells and a secretion rate of new tissue material that is proportional to cell density. In this project we include cell proliferation, apoptosis (death) and embedment as stochastic processes. This model is solved using the DifferentialEquations.jl and ElasticArrays.jl packages. The solver uses RK4() or Euler() solving algorithms with a constant timestep $\Delta t$. The stochastic cell behaviour is implemented using a PeriodicCallback and occurs every $\delta t_{\text{event}}$ period of time. This package offers 1D and 2D simulations. In our case 1D simulations imply the evolution of a line segment which has periodic boundaries and 2D is a closed domain. In the case of 2D simulations you can choose an inward or outward growth simulation by setting the appropriate parameters.

Model Description

This cell-based mathematical model

Calculates the mechanical relaxation and normal velocity in a system with periodic boundary conditions. The derivatives are based on the discrete equation given by:

\[\frac{\text{d}\mathbf{u}·µ¢}{\text{d}t} = \frac{1}{Œ∑}\bigg((\mathbf{F}‚Çõ‚Å∫ - \mathbf{F}‚Çõ‚Åª)\cdot\bm{œÑ}\bigg)\bm{œÑ} + V‚Çô\mathbf{n} \]

where,

\[\mathbf{F}‚Çõ‚Å∫ = f(\lVert \mathbf{u}·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ - \mathbf{u}·µ¢ \rVert) \frac{\mathbf{u}·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ - \mathbf{u}·µ¢}{\lVert \mathbf{u}·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ - \mathbf{u}·µ¢ \rVert}, \hspace{0.5cm} \mathbf{F}‚Çõ‚Åª = f(\lVert \mathbf{u}·µ¢ - \mathbf{u}·µ¢‚Çã‚ÇÅ \rVert) \frac{\mathbf{u}·µ¢ - \mathbf{u}·µ¢‚Çã‚ÇÅ}{\lVert \mathbf{u}·µ¢ - \mathbf{u}·µ¢‚Çã‚ÇÅ \rVert}\]

given $f(\lVert \mathbf{u}·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ - \mathbf{u}·µ¢ \rVert)$ is the restoration force function and $V‚Çô$ is the velocity in the normal direction.

Current models of Mechanical Relaxation and Normal Velocity

In this current version of the simulation code we use a nonlinear resorting force given by,

\[f(\lVert \mathbf{u}·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ - \mathbf{u}·µ¢ \rVert) = k‚Çõ \bigg(\frac{1}{l_{0}} - \frac{1}{\lVert \mathbf{u}·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ - \mathbf{u}·µ¢ \rVert }\bigg)\]

and a normal velocity which is proportional to density such that,

\[V‚Çô = k_{f}\rho_{i}, \hspace{0.5cm} \rho_{i} = \frac{1}{\lVert \mathbf{u}·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ - \mathbf{u}·µ¢ \rVert}\]

User Set Parameters

N: Number of cells in the simulation. [Integer]

m: Number of springs per cell. [Integer]

R‚ÇÄ: Radius or characteristic length of the initial shape. [Float]

D: Array of diffuision coefficients used to calculate cell stiffness. [Float]

l‚ÇÄ: Resting length of the spring per cell. [Float]

kf: Tissue production rate per cell. [Float]

Œ∑: Viscosity or damping coefficient per cell. [Float]

growth_dir: Direction of tissue growth (Options: 'inward' or 'outward'). [String]

Tmax: Total simulation time (in days). [Float]

Œ¥t: Time step for the numerical integration. [Float]

btypes: Types of boundary conditions (Options: "Sinewave" (1D only), "circle", "triangle", "square", "hex", "star", "cross"). [String]

dist_type: Distribution type for node placement ("Linear", "sigmoid", "2sigmoid", "exp", "sine", "cosine", "quad", "cubic"). [String]

prolif, death, embed: Boolean flags indicating cell behaviors. [Boolean]

Œ±, Œ≤, Œ≥: Parameters for cell behaviors. [Float]

event_Œ¥t: Time interval for periodic callback events. [Float]

The stochastic cell behaviour has not been implemented in the 1D simulation code therefore a set of parameters would not be set/ required to run those simulations.

Data Structure

TissueGrowth.SimResults_t ‚Äî Type
SimResults_t

A data structure representing the results of a simulation which can then be used for visualisation with the plotting code PlottingFncs1D.jl and PlottingFncs2D.jl.

This structure contains various fields that store the results and relevant data from a simulation process. It includes the type of simulation, time steps, state vectors, forces, densities, and other relevant quantities.

Fields

  • btype: A String indicating the type of simulation or boundary condition.
  • t: A Vector{Float64} representing the time steps at which the simulation results are recorded.
  • u: A Vector of ElasticMatrix{Float64,Vector{Float64}} representing the state of the system at each time step.
  • ‚àëF: A Vector of ElasticVector{Float64,Vector{Float64}}, representing the sum of forces at each time step.
  • Density: A Vector of ElasticMatrix{Float64,Vector{Float64}} representing the density of the system at each time step.
  • V‚Çô: A Vector{Vector{Float64}} representing the normal velocity at each time step.
  • Œ©: A Vector{Float64} representing the void area within the pore at each time step.
  • œà: A Vector of ElasticMatrix{Float64,Vector{Float64}}, representing the stress of the springs/ cells at each time step.
  • Œö: A Vector of ElasticMatrix{Float64,Vector{Float64}}, representing the approximate curvature of the moving boundary at each time step.
source

1D simulation code:

TissueGrowth.sim1D ‚Äî Method
sim1D()

Execute a series of 1D mechanical relaxation simulations.

This function sets up and runs a series of 1D simulations for different stiffness values. It iterates over an array of stiffness coefficients, sets up the corresponding ODE problem for each case, solves it, and collects the results.

Simulation Parameters

  • N: Number of cells in the simulation.
  • m: Number of springs per cell.
  • M: Total number of springs along the interface.
  • R‚ÇÄ: Radius or characteristic length of the initial shape.
  • D: Array of diffuision coefficients used to calculate cell stiffness.
  • l‚ÇÄ: Resting length of the spring per cell.
  • kf: Tissue production rate per cell.
  • Œ∑: Viscosity or damping coefficient per cell.
  • Tmax: Total simulation time (in days).
  • Œ¥t: Time step for the Euler integration.
  • growth_dir: Growth direction for the simulation ('1D').
  • btype: Type of boundary condition ('SineWave').
  • savetimes: Time points at which to save the simulation results.

Returns

A vector of SimResults_t objects, each representing the simulation results for a different stiffness coefficient.

source

2D simulation code:

TissueGrowth.sim2D ‚Äî Method
sim2D()

Execute a series of 2D mechanical relaxation simulations.

This function sets up and runs 2D simulations for different stiffness coefficients and boundary types. It iterates over arrays of stiffness coefficients and boundary types, sets up the corresponding ODE problem for each case, solves it using a specified numerical method with periodic callbacks, and collects the results.

Simulation Parameters

  • N: Number of cells in the simulation.
  • m: Number of springs per cell.
  • M: Total number of springs along the interface.
  • R‚ÇÄ: Radius or characteristic length of the initial shape.
  • D: Array of diffuision coefficients used to calculate cell stiffness.
  • l‚ÇÄ: Resting length of the spring per cell.
  • kf: Tissue production rate per cell.
  • Œ∑: Viscosity or damping coefficient per cell.
  • growth_dir: Direction of tissue growth ('inward' or 'outward').
  • Tmax: Total simulation time (in days).
  • Œ¥t: Time step for the numerical integration.
  • btypes: Types of boundary conditions (e.g., 'circle', 'triangle').
  • dist_type: Distribution type for node placement (e.g., 'Linear', 'sigmoid').
  • prolif, death, embed: Boolean flags indicating cell behaviors.
  • Œ±, Œ≤, Œ≥: Parameters for cell behaviors.
  • event_Œ¥t: Time interval for periodic callback events.
  • savetimes: Time points at which to save the simulation results.

Returns

A vector of vectors of SimResults_t objects. Each inner vector represents the simulation results for different boundary types under a specific stiffness coefficient.

Example

all_results = sim2D()
source

ODE Problem:

TissueGrowth.ODE_fnc_1D! ‚Äî Method
ODE_fnc_1D!(du, u, p, t)

Define the ODE system for 1D mechanical relaxation with initial conditions. This function computes the derivatives du based on the current state u and parameters p. In this system there is a periodic boundary condition such that x ‚àà [0,2œÄ] with i spring boundary nodes and u‚Çã‚ÇÅ = u‚Çô, u‚Çô‚Çä‚ÇÅ = u‚ÇÅ

Arguments

  • du: Array to store the derivatives of u.
  • u: Current state array.
  • p: Parameters tuple (N, k‚Çõ, Œ∑, kf, l‚ÇÄ, Œ¥t, growth_dir).
  • t: Current time.

Description

Calculates the mechanical relaxation and normal velocity in a 1D system with periodic boundary conditions. The derivatives are based on spring forces and mechanical properties defined in p.

source
TissueGrowth.ODE_fnc_2D! ‚Äî Method
ODE_fnc_2D!(du, u, p, t)

Define the ODE system for 2D mechanical relaxation with initial conditions. This function computes the derivatives du based on the current state u and parameters p.

Arguments

  • du: Array to store the derivatives of u.
  • u: Current position array of all spring boundary nodes.
  • p: Parameters tuple (N, k‚Çõ, Œ∑, kf, l‚ÇÄ, Œ¥t, growth_dir).
  • t: Current time.

Description

Calculates the mechanical relaxation and normal velocity in a 1D system with periodic boundary conditions. The derivatives are based on spring forces and mechanical properties defined in p.

source

Equations for ODE problem:

TissueGrowth.Œ¥ ‚Äî Method
Œ¥(r·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ, r·µ¢)

Calculate the Euclidean distance between two points r·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ and r·µ¢.

Arguments

  • r·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ: The first point in space.
  • r·µ¢: The second point in space.

Returns

The Euclidean distance between the two points.

source
TissueGrowth.œÅ ‚Äî Method
œÅ(r·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ, r·µ¢)

Calculate the reciprocal of the distance (interpreted as density) between two points r·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ and r·µ¢.

Arguments

  • r·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ: The first point in space.
  • r·µ¢: The second point in space.

Returns

The reciprocal of the distance between the two points.

source
TissueGrowth.œÑ ‚Äî Method
œÑ(r·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ, r·µ¢‚Çã‚ÇÅ)

Calculate the unit tangent vector between two neighboring points r·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ and r·µ¢‚Çã‚ÇÅ.

Arguments

  • r·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ: The point after the central point in space.
  • r·µ¢‚Çã‚ÇÅ: The point before the central point in space.

Returns

The unit tangent vector between the two points.

source
TissueGrowth.n ‚Äî Method
n(r·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ, r·µ¢‚Çã‚ÇÅ, type)

Calculate the unit normal vector at a point r·µ¢ between two neighboring points r·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ and r·µ¢‚Çã‚ÇÅ. The orientation of the normal vector depends on the specified type.

Arguments

  • r·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ: The point after the central point in space.
  • r·µ¢‚Çã‚ÇÅ: The point before the central point in space.
  • type: A string specifying the orientation of the normal vector, either "inward" or any other value for outward orientation.

Returns

The unit normal vector at the point.

source
TissueGrowth.F‚Çõ‚Å∫ ‚Äî Method
F‚Çõ‚Å∫(r·µ¢, r·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ, r·µ¢‚Çã‚ÇÅ, k‚Çõ, l‚ÇÄ)

Calculate the spring force (Nonlinear) for mechanical relaxation in the positive direction.

Arguments

  • r·µ¢: The current point in space.
  • r·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ: The point after the current point in space.
  • r·µ¢‚Çã‚ÇÅ: The point before the current point in space.
  • k‚Çõ: Spring coefficient.
  • l‚ÇÄ: Resting length of the spring.

Returns

The spring force in the positive direction.

source
TissueGrowth.F‚Çõ‚Åª ‚Äî Method
F‚Çõ‚Åª(r·µ¢, r·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ, r·µ¢‚Çã‚ÇÅ, k‚Çõ, l‚ÇÄ)

Calculate the spring force (Nonlinear) for mechanical relaxation in the negative direction.

Arguments

  • r·µ¢: The current point in space.
  • r·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ: The point after the current point in space.
  • r·µ¢‚Çã‚ÇÅ: The point before the current point in space.
  • k‚Çõ: Spring coefficient.
  • l‚ÇÄ: Resting length of the spring.

Returns

The spring force in the negative direction.

source
TissueGrowth.V‚Çô ‚Äî Method
V‚Çô(r·µ¢‚Çã‚ÇÅ, r·µ¢, r·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ, kf, Œ¥t, type)

Calculate the normal velocity of the interface such that V‚Çô is proportional to œÅ. The direction of the normal vector is determined by type.

Arguments

  • r·µ¢‚Çã‚ÇÅ: The point before the current point in space.
  • r·µ¢: The current point in space.
  • r·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ: The point after the current point in space.
  • kf: The amount of tissue produced per unit area per unit time.
  • Œ¥t: The time step.
  • type: A string specifying the orientation of the normal vector, either "inward" or any other value for outward orientation.

Returns

The normal velocity of the interface.

source
TissueGrowth.Œ∫ ‚Äî Method
Œ∫(r·µ¢‚Çã‚ÇÅ, r·µ¢, r·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ)

Approximate the curvature of a shape using the Menger method. This method is based on the areas of triangles formed by consecutive triplets of points.

Arguments

  • r·µ¢‚Çã‚ÇÅ: The point before the current point in space.
  • r·µ¢: The current point in space.
  • r·µ¢‚Çä‚ÇÅ: The point after the current point in space.

Returns

The approximated curvature at the point r·µ¢.

Reference

Anoshkina, Elena V., Alexander G. Belyaev, and Hans-Peter Seidel. "Asymtotic Analysis of Three-Point Approximations of Vertex Normals and Curvatures." VMV. 2002.

source

Cell behaviour functions:

TissueGrowth.P ‚Äî Method
P(event, œÅ, Œ±)

Calculate the probability of proliferation occurring, given the density œÅ and the parameter Œ±.

If the proliferation event is considered to occur (event is true), the probability is calculated as the product of œÅ and Œ±. Otherwise, a vector of zeros is returned.

Arguments

  • event: A boolean indicating whether the proliferation event is considered to occur.
  • œÅ: A vector representing densities.
  • Œ±: Parameter for scaling the proliferation probability.

Returns

A vector representing the calculated probabilities for proliferation.

source
TissueGrowth.A ‚Äî Method
A(event, œÅ, Œ≤)

Calculate the probability of apoptosis (cell death) occurring, given the density œÅ and the parameter Œ≤.

If the apoptosis event is considered to occur (event is true), the probability is calculated as the product of œÅ and Œ≤. Otherwise, a vector of zeros is returned.

Arguments

  • event: A boolean indicating whether the apoptosis event is considered to occur.
  • œÅ: A vector representing densities.
  • Œ≤: Parameter for scaling the apoptosis probability.

Returns

A vector representing the calculated probabilities for apoptosis.

source
TissueGrowth.E ‚Äî Method
E(event, œÅ, Œ≥)

Calculate the probability of embedding occurring, given the density œÅ and the parameter Œ≥.

If the embedding event is considered to occur (event is true), the probability is calculated as the product of œÅ and Œ≥. Otherwise, a vector of zeros is returned.

Arguments

  • event: A boolean indicating whether the embedding event is considered to occur.
  • œÅ: A vector representing densities.
  • Œ≥: Parameter for scaling the embedding probability.

Returns

A vector representing the calculated probabilities for embedding.

source
TissueGrowth.affect! ‚Äî Method
affect!(integrator)

Update the state of integrator based on probabilistic cellular events.

This function modifies integrator in place. It uses the parameters and state from integrator to compute probabilities for different cellular events: proliferation (prolif), death (death), and embedding (embed). Based on these probabilities and random draws, it updates the state of integrator.

Arguments

  • integrator: The integrator object containing the current state and parameters. The parameters are expected to be a tuple containing:

Returns

nothing. The function modifies integrator in place.

source
TissueGrowth.store_embed_cell_pos ‚Äî Method
store_embed_cell_pos(pos)

Stores the position of embedded cells into ü•î array.

This function inserts the position vector pos of an embedded cell into the ü•î array.

Arguments

  • pos: position vector of the cell that is being embedded into the tissue should contain m+1 values given m springs in the simulation

Returns

nothing. The function modifies ü•î in place.

Custom modifier functions

Base.insert! ‚Äî Function
Base.insert!(A::ElasticMatrix, col, xy)

Insert a two-element vector xy into a specific column col of an ElasticMatrix A.

This function modifies the ElasticMatrix in place. It inserts the elements of xy into the underlying data of A at the positions corresponding to the specified column.

Arguments

  • A::ElasticMatrix: The ElasticMatrix object to be modified.
  • col: The column index where the elements will be inserted.
  • xy: A two-element vector containing the values to be inserted into the matrix.

Returns

The modified ElasticMatrix A.

source
Base.deleteat! ‚Äî Function
Base.deleteat!(A::ElasticMatrix, col)

Delete elements from a specific column col of an ElasticMatrix A.

This function modifies the ElasticMatrix in place. It removes the elements of the specified column from the underlying data of A.

Arguments

  • A::ElasticMatrix: The ElasticMatrix object to be modified.
  • col: The column index from which the elements will be removed.

Returns

The modified ElasticMatrix A.
